projects.title: Ariel Machine Learning Data Challenge 2023
projects.description:
I implement several SOTA simulation-based inference (SBI) methods, all based Neural Posterior Estimation (NPE) Normalizing Flows (NF). I focus on amortized methods that are robust to the missspecified model and out-of-distribution (OOD) test data. To this end I implement two distribution discrepancy estimators; Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD) and  d-dimensional Kolmogorov-Smirnov Test (ddKS). I make use of the PyTorch, LAMPE and ZUKO libraries to implement the NPE, MMD and ddKS. 

Training takes between 5 and 30 minutes depending mostly on the distribution discrepancy estimator. Inference of a single observation is nearly instantaneous on the order of milliseconds for all models.

contributors.headline: Dual Master Student at TU Delft and Leiden University

projects.title: Compatibility of Inhomogeneous Datasets of Transiting Exoplanets - Differences in Exoplanet Atmosphere Characterization
projects.description: In this study, significant disparities between different datasets are found, indicating potential incompatibilities when these datasets are combined. The statistical tests used in this study demonstrate that the datasets from different instruments do not sample the same underlying distribution. This is particularly highlighted in the case of HD 209458 b, where a considerable offset between STIS and G141 datasets was observed. Similarly, for WASP-76 b, variations in the offsets ranging from 350 to 1000 ppm were identified. This evidence casts doubt on the hypothesis that data from different space-based instruments can be combined seamlessly, without considering instrument compatibility.

contributors.headline: Dual Master Student at TU Delft and Leiden University

projects.title: Recurrence and Pseudo Random Exploration for Adversarially Guided Actor-Critic
projects.description: Reimplementation and extension of AGAC to make use of recurrence for long term memory and pseudo random exploration to boost risk taking behavior.

contributors.headline: Dual Master Student at TU Delft and Leiden University

projects.title: Compliant pressurization mechanism and propellant storage system for Vaporizing Liquid Micro-resistojet (VLM)
projects.description: In this project I designed a propellant storage system (PSS) using a compliant mechanism for pressurization. The design covers all aspects of the PSS, including control and sensing. The compliant mechanism allows a novel tank configuration which significantly reduces PSS mass, volume and increases the propellant mass fraction. The most notable innovation of this design is the elimination of ullage.

contributors.headline: Dual Master Student at TU Delft and Leiden University

projects.title: Computational Physics: N-body, Ising-Model, Angular-Spectrum Method
projects.description:
N-body: I simulate argon atoms in different states using Velocity-Verlet numerical integration. Additionally, we implement spheres of influence using truncated potentials for more efficient large-scale simulations.
Ising-Model: I simulate a 2D lattice of interacting spins in order to find spontaneous magnetization regions and phase transitions. I make use of GPU-computing and spin-interaction kernels. I propose a novel solution to the problem of spin auto-correlation for small lattices with large spin-interaction kernels.
Angular-Spectrum Method: I simulate forward diffraction of multi-specrtral light using the angular-spectrum method. I make use of GPU-computing for efficient matrix operations. I verify this method by comparing real and simulated response to incoming multi-spectral light in the human eye. I additionally recover known diffraction patterns for different slits from the simulated experiments.

contributors.headline: Dual Master Student at TU Delft and Leiden University

projects.title: Deep Reinforcement Learning Methods
projects.description: Implementing and testing deep reinforcement learning (DRL) algorithms from Double Deep Q-Learning (DDQN) to Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) using Python and TensorFlow.

contributors.headline: Dual Master Student at TU Delft and Leiden University

projects.title: Design of an Optical Schlieren System
projects.description: As part of a 3 student team I designed, produced, calibrated and tested a low-cost Schlieren Imaging System for solid rocket propellant grain ignition characterization. As part of this effort I developed a modular optical bench as well as lens mounts with 1, 2, 3 and 5 degrees of freedom that seamlessly integrate with commercial lenses.

contributors.headline: Dual Master Student at TU Delft and Leiden University

projects.title: Space Tug Design for OSAM
projects.description: Design of a semi-autonomous Space Tug for on-orbit servicing, assembly and maintenance of space systems, specifically commercial satellites and space stations. As part of a 10 student team I worked on the design of spacial awareness, sensing and adaptive control systems as well as risk assessment.

contributors.headline: Dual Master Student at TU Delft and Leiden University

projects.title: QWIP and T2SL Detectors for Space Applications
projects.description: In this essay I give an overview of the basic physics of both QWIPs and T2SL and SLS. I relate the physics and the resulting detector properties to two space-based applications; detection of asteroids and detection of space debris. For the former, IR detectors in general and both QWIPs and T2SL(S) based telescopes would offer a significant and necessary addition to current capabilities. I identify the radiation hardness of QWIPs as an important aspect for the design of small scale space telescopes. For the detection of space debris, space-based IR telescopes fill the essential niche of detecting objects smaller than a few cm. The inherent ease of detecting the polarization of light with QWIPs is a significant advantage over other detector types. This would give laser systems for deorbiting space debris the ability to effectively choose targets for efficient operation. I identify the temperature increase of the targeted objects as a novel opportunity for synergy between these deorbiting systems and space-based object tracking IR telescopes.

contributors.headline: Dual Master Student at TU Delft and Leiden University

projects.title: Effect of Planet Migration on Dust Rings
projects.description: In this work an overview of the current state of research into the interactions of migrating planets and disks was developed. The interactions have implications on planet formation as well as disk evolution and structure. Disks perturbed by planets migrating at a fast or intermediate rate have unambiguous features visible to ALMA and ngVLA. Furthermore, a single intermittently migrating planet can cause multiple rings and gaps. There is general agreement about the structure and dynamics of disks and migrating planets, however some smaller scale processes are not fully explored and might have implications for the larger structure. I find that implementing evolving mesh geometries, such as localized wavelet compression, will significantly improve model accuracy without increasing computational effort. These meshes are ideally suited to simulate the turbulent, multi-species and compressible flows which requires accuracy over many order of magnitude in both space and time Its disadvantages, loss of resolution at the highest frequencies, are not significant as those are resolvable by neither ALMA nor ngVLA. Further disk surveys by ALMA and ngVLA, expanding observational capabilities as well as validating model assumptions and expanding them are promising areas for future work.

contributors.headline: Dual Master Student at TU Delft and Leiden University

projects.title: Solar Concentrator Swarm for Hazardous Asteroid Redirection
projects.description:
Asteroid impacts pose a significant threat to the Earth and everything living on it. Impacts by asteroids 10 km in size can cause global extinction events. However, “city-killer” asteroids, 10-100 m in size, impact much more frequently, and can still have devastating effects. These asteroids are more difficult to detect, meaning they are often not detected until shortly before a potential impact. Very few concepts have been proposed for deflecting these smaller asteroids. It is necessary to design a system that can reliably redirect small asteroids within a short time period.

A preliminary mission and system design resulted in a solar concentrator system which outgasses the asteroid. Its unique optical arrangement for asteroid outgassing combined with an active cleaning mechanism is a novel solution to the largest problem of solar concentrator designs. All large structures of the spacecraft are deployable.

With a swarm of 32 spacecraft each with a 60 m radius parabolic reflector, we estimate that the system can redirect 49% of asteroids 10-100 m in diameter which are detected two years before impact. The system can easily be scaled by adding additional spacecraft. This would enable redirection of larger asteroids.

contributors.headline: Dual Master Student at TU Delft and Leiden University

projects.title: Preliminary design of an attitude determination and control system.
projects.description: This report presents a preliminary design of an attitude determination and control system [ADCS] for the Mars Orbiter which is supposed to map the surface of Mars. Firstly, potential orbits for the spacecraft are identified and the driving requirement for the ADCS is established. Using this a requirement analysis is performed which finds 6 main requirements. This leads to a preliminary ADCS design. Lastly, a power and mass budget is developed in accordance with the requirements.

contributors.headline: Dual Master Student at TU Delft and Leiden University

projects.title: Simulated Aileron Response to Aerodynamic loading.
projects.description: A simulation was developed to predict the structural response of an aileron due to aerodynamic loading. A simulation plan, verification and validation procedures were developed. The validation of the simulation was based on reference loading responses as predicted by an external FEA. After identifying an error in the given, external FEA reference model the validation was successfully conducted.

contributors.headline: Dual Master Student at TU Delft and Leiden University

projects.title: The 55 Cancri binary system and the possibility of an stellar envelope ejection due to 55 Cnc f.
projects.description: 55 Cnc is a binary star system with one super Earth and four gas planets orbiting a central G-type star. While no planets are currently in the habitable zone, hypothetical moons of 55 Cnc f might meet the conditions for life and would continue to do so until 19 Gyrs from now, when it will enter 55 Cnc A and be destroyed because the energy dumped into it by 55 Cnc A will surpass its binding energy. During the RGB-phase of 55 Cnc A an ejection of its envelope is probable due to the additional momentum of the inner planets.

contributors.headline: Dual Master Student at TU Delft and Leiden University

projects.title: Evaluation of Structural Responseto Actuation in a Morphing Wing.
projects.description: In order to reduce carbon dioxide emissions as well as aerodynamic noise, a morphing leading edge mechanism was developed at Delft University of Technology as part of the CleanSky-project. The structural performance of the morphing leading edge design is evaluated in this article through numerical methods and experimental data, generating the structural response to actuation, as well as the work performed by the system. The findings were as follows:  Firstly, the actuator’s work done is linear with increasing extension. Secondly, the strain observed in the airfoil skin during morphing is predominantly bending.  Finally, this paper concludes an overall good agreement between the finite element method (FEM) and the experimental strain data. However, the FEM significantly underpredicts the required actuation force.   Additionally to the evaluation of the performance, safety-related aspects of the mechanism were analysed.  It is recommended to review the FEM in order to increase accuracy near the stringers and improve its actuation force prediction.

profile_positions.company: SRON Netherlands Institute for Space Research
profile_positions.description: Impact of Inhomogeneous Datasets on Comparative Planetology. In this internship I show that assuming space-based instrument comparability for exoplanet atmosphere retrievals biases the retrieval results. Further, my findings indicate the offset between space-based instruments can be as large as between ground- and space-based instruments, even between mature instruments on the HST. These findings have implications for our current understanding of exoplanet atmospheres and the science from instruments such as ARIEL and JWST.
